@MaikNog The article you linked is really interesting. I like the way they laid it all out. Thanks for sharing!

@MaikNog Totally. I think the main takeaway is that everyone prefers different things, at different times. Identifying and addressing the current need is a skill. I just found it interesting to notice the connection between my usual preference and style.

@LarsSjodahl @YvesHanoulle I don't think that's a fair comparison, because we're discussing sentence structure, whereas your alternative introduces new information. The correct alternative would be, "we're low on memory, so you only get 24h logs now".
@andersdinsen That's true. Communication needs to be adapted to the audience and situation to be most effective... You might even say they're the "why" of why you chose a particular approach 🌚😛
@LarsSjodahl Yeah, that for sure is a skill. Like, just tell me what's relevant. It's very, "I would have written a shorter letter, but I didn't have the time". Editing is a skill.

@LarsSjodahl A downside I've experienced of giving the what first is that people are so distracted by the what, that they don't even listen to the why. So it's sometimes necessary to give the why first, so they hear it and can process it before they blow up on the what.

@LarsSjodahl I get that. I can definitely hear myself sometimes sounding mysterious like, "I'm telling you a 'why' without telling you why I'm telling you why / what for" 🤔 it's something I do subconsciously and have to actively try not to do when it's not just a quick / simple thing.

"Since x is y, I did z" vs "I did z since x is y"

"Because of x, we'll need to y" vs "We'll need to y because of x"

"So long as x, let's do y" vs "Let's do y, so long as x"

"I don't like x, so I went with y" vs "I went with y, since I don't like x"

I always like to know why. Reason and context help me understand and respond. Today, I realised this is reflected in my sentence structure. I give the why before the what (examples in thread). Is your learning style also reflected in your delivery of everyday information? How?

@darktelecom @CAkehurstRyan @DanAshby04 @FullSnackTester @TestnSolve This reminds me of how people say, "the good thing about McDonald's is that it's the same wherever you go". But it's not. They change their menu and ingredients to meet the needs / tastes / preferences of every market.
@CAkehurstRyan @DanAshby04 @FullSnackTester "assess", not "assert" 😉
@DaveyBoyWardlaw "like everything it depends on the context" https://t.co/FfMRhjTtKn

@DaveyBoyWardlaw Does that mean assessing quality can only happen in production? Can user metrics only be used to guide testing in this context? What about using metrics to interpret / extract an assessment?

@rforjoe Interesting... If assessing quality isn't a skill, what is it? Do you see the close relationship the others speak of, or would you not even speak of it anyway due to the broadness you mentioned?

RT @witchofthetest: #Testers assemble! The first of the three give-away tickets for Test.bash(); is gone but you can still get your hands o…
@DanAshby04 @FullSnackTester @nicolasedgwick https://t.co/tW56g3TP5f

@DanAshby04 @kinofrost @nicolasedgwick @FullSnackTester Who you calling "hen"?! 😠😅 okay, so then that is to say that when a tester reports back on their testing, they are only relaying their own perception of quality and not their assessment of quality?

@DanAshby04 @FullSnackTester @nicolasedgwick "test" is a noun, "testing" is a verb, as most "-ing" words are. As the author of this thread, I must advise that the perspective I wrote it from was as "testing" as a verb 😅 sorry, buddy 😉

@DanAshby04 @kinofrost @nicolasedgwick @FullSnackTester But an evaluation can also be a result! 😅 I'm seeing an emerging pattern of us interpreting the same words in different ways, which is fascinating and important in itself. What do you think is the result of a test / assessment / evaluation then? What does a test produce?
@FullSnackTester @garyfleming No worries. I've since seen your subsequent replies, which cleared things up for me!
@kinofrost @DanAshby04 @nicolasedgwick @FullSnackTester What's your take on that?

@DanAshby04 @kinofrost @nicolasedgwick @FullSnackTester That's a very interesting distinction. Is the outcome of a test always an assessment then, in your view? Or can a test produce something else without there being an assessment? Is an additional step required between the execution of the test and getting making the assessment?
@DanAshby04 @nicolasedgwick @FullSnackTester This thread in particular has sparked another question for me... What's the difference between an assessment and an opinion? Is there a difference?
@nicolasedgwick @TestingChef Tell me more about that... What does observing quality involve? Can you also observe the absence of quality? How would you know?
@TestingChef Gotta go read up on blacksmithing now 😜
@TestnSolve @ministryoftest Can something still be of good quality if the KPIs suggest that a problem isn't solved? How can we assess the quality of the KPIs?

@tirmizi26 The question was about "testing" vs "_assessing_ quality", not "testing" vs "quality" 🙂 you used "evaluating" in your definition of testing though... So would that be the same as "assessing" here, therefore concluding that they are the same?
@wood_brothers21 Is that to say that the value of testing is capped by the number of bugs in a SUT?

@garyfleming @FullSnackTester Ben followed up with some sources of information one might refer to without necessarily calling "testing", or maybe that one would call "testing in production". Interested in what you think of those and whether that changes your current view.
@pulkit_LFC Is "ensuring" the same as "guaranteeing" in this context? How can you do that? What is assessing quality? Or do you think that exists?
@TestnSolve @ministryoftest Can something still be of good quality if the KPIs aren't met, or do you see this falling under the "scope change" you mentioned?
@Intentionaut Is it the testing that gets the code to do the thing without bugs or the implementation of the code / thing? Is quality only a mindset, or can it be a characteristic of the thing?
@FullSnackTester @garyfleming Very interesting indeed! Now... Who is "qualified" to make an accurate / useful assessment of quality? What happens when two people disagree? I'm pushing, I know 😜
@garyfleming @FullSnackTester Is that to say that you can't assess quality without testing?
@andy_hird @ministryoftest Interesting! What would be the result of the overlap if you were to do / have both?
@FullSnackTester @garyfleming I'm struggling to read that last sentence 😅 could you rephrase, possibly with more words than a single tweet allows?
@DougJessie What does it mean to manage quality? Does assessing quality come in anywhere for you?

@wood_brothers21 Does that mean that any test that doesn't find a bug is not a successful test, and that testing can only be successful if the SUT has bugs that we find? Have we "failed" at testing is we don't find bugs?
@TestingChef Is it possible to have the information necessary to assess quality without deliberately testing? Either directly yourself, or through someone else?
@c_d_los Do you think it's possible to test well without discovering all the bugs that exist? How would you know whether you've achieved this? Can the two definitions be combined, in your opinion?
@wood_brothers21 Does that mean testing is unsuccessful if it doesn't find bugs? What is an indication of quality?
@FullSnackTester Very interesting! Honing in on the first part, am I right in thinking that @FullSnackTester and @garyfleming both see a parent/child relationship, but in opposite directions?

@TestnSolve @ministryoftest Interesting! Does that mean you think quality is something that can be "reached" or "completed"? Can you go backwards after "passing" the milestone? Is there another milestone after quality?
Question: Is #testing the same thing as assessing #quality, or are these two distinct skills? Why?

@ivistrunk I haven't yet. That part is still locked, leaving me to obsess and sob limitlessly without treatment...

It helps to get it out of my head, to visualise it, to put it in a format semi-suitable for consumption... It gives me something to talk about and point to when I'm struggling to explain it. You don't even know how much else I'm holding in my brain.

I didn't think of it to make this, I made this because I was thinking it. I'm trying to organise my thoughts and understand what's happening. People are asking me stuff, and I don't know what to tell them. This will be the first of a few, at least...

To be very clear, this is not a plan. It's a visualisation and tool for communication. This stuff was already in my head, it was just floating around. This is just a snippet of what it already looks like in my brain.

Don’t feel bad about my criticisms, or that you’re not doing enough. Start now: Listen, act, change.

Don’t roll your eyes at another angry non-white, non-straight, non-man ranting on the internet. Open your eyes, and be angry too.

"If you’re not angry, you’re not paying attention."

Don’t act like #gender is the only point of #discrimination worth talking about or tackling. Understand that compound effects make life even harder for #intersectional people belonging to multiple minorities / underrepresented groups.

Don’t think that only women / NBs suffer from misogyny and sexism. Understand that #toxicmasculinity has the same roots in seeing women and femininity as lesser, weaker. That results in both murder and suicide, all over the world.
Don’t wonder why I’m even mentioning #nonbinary people in this thread.  Recognise that there are more than two genders, that trans women are women, that women’s and trans rights are human rights.
Don’t tell women / NBs how to not be attacked. Teach people to not attack women / NBs.

Don’t only highlight achievements and successes that are easy to talk about. Draw attention to tough topics, like #abortionrights #rapeculture #periodpoverty and the fact that many girls and women around the world still aren’t allowed to go to school, to name just a few.
Don’t claim that women / NBs just aren’t interested in [tech, science, leadership, etc.]. Look into what makes these areas so toxic, and do something to fix it.

Don’t only highlight women / NBs you feel have done enough to be considered “exceptional”. Appreciate that many of us are already putting in massive amounts of effort just to get through the day and don’t have time or energy to put towards things you might even consider ordinary.

Don’t enlist women / NBs to create your content, so you can feel good about yourself for recognising the “holiday”, or aligning yourself with us. Recognise that we already carry various unfair burdens simply because of our gender, and take on some of the labour yourself.

This #IWD, and every day, don’t use #women and #nonbinary people as marketing ploys to make yourself look better. Take real actions within your area of control that will affect positive change, even if that means time and effort beyond one day.

#InternationalWomensDay thread / rant

Brace yourselves, cos I’m coming in with real talk, and you might not like it.

@TheWylieKyote Nice one! Nothing quite like real-world testing. Luckily for me, this hardware is designed to be used in a location that doesn't change during use.

And no, I don't have time to order something and wait for it to arrive. I gotta be resourceful! 💪😎 Findings are that effectiveness depends on thickness, seal, and reflectiveness, in case you feel like trying something similar 😉

I also tried just foil - needed to be several layers, wrapped multiple times, and it became less and less effective the more scrunched (less shiny) it became. Also tried the microwave, fridge, dishwasher, oven, metal pot, thick metal oven trays sandwiched together...!

@lisacrispin Great to hear, Lisa, and I hope others do too 🙂

It's likely that we all still have some implicit biases that go against what we believe to be right and proper, which is why it's so important to learn about, and actively tackle, our biases.

What are your biases, and how do they manifest? 9/9

What's interesting is that the pre-test questionnaires show bias in the people behind Project Implicit too, via the (lack of) options for sex, ethnicity, race, and sexual orientation. For 3/4, I didn't know what to pick because my identity wasn't included. I was #othered. 8/9 https://t.co/1AvrcFcun0

Info on the meaning of "slight", "moderate" and "strong" automatic preferences: https://t.co/MurGJxrsY8

Take the UK tests in English: https://t.co/E0UuzSlCmw

Tests for other countries and languages: https://t.co/yPrG1aiZRP

I encourage you to share your results here too. 7/9

...
- Strong association of male with science and female with liberal arts
- Slight for gay over straight people
- Slight for UK over USA
- Moderate for young over old people
6/9 https://t.co/OzQs14Kpkb

Using Project Implicit's wording, my results indicate the following "automatic preferences":
- Slight for white over black people
- Slight for dark over light -skinned people
- Strong for fat over thin people
...
5/9 https://t.co/qv2yuNuSYX

If we know what our biases are, we can hold ourselves accountable and take steps towards combating them. That's why I did the tests and, in the interest of transparency and wanting to be held accountable, that's why I'm sharing my results here with you too. 4/9

When it comes to the presence of biases and prejudice, the finger is often pointed at society in general, but not towards ourselves. For society to improve, we all need to improve as individuals, and uncover things about ourselves we may not like, such as our implicit biases. 3/9

But how can we find out what our implicit biases are? These online tests from Project Implicit might help: https://t.co/yPrG1aiZRP

Of course, they're only a gauge and not 100% accurate, but they can be a first step towards solving a big problem - realising there is one. 2/9

Unconscious / implicit #bias is something we talk about often in this community. And rightly so - it affects many things, both in our personal lives and in our work, which in turn affects other people's lives. Sometimes, it can even be the difference between life and death. 1/9

@fox 1st / 2nd unless it's a hyperlink. Conversational, addressing the reader as myself. Use my actual name in some hyperlinks so they're meaningful out of context. 3rd person seems really staged to me when I know the person is writing about themselves and it's not an off-site bio.

RT @TestPappy: Dear IT folks, I know working with shiny new tools is awesome. But often the problems in projects emerge due to a lack of ba…

My point is: it's not just product decisions that affect users. Infra/structural and process decisions impact users too. What do you take into account when making non-product-related decisions? Do you think about users?

From the company's view, maybe it seemed easier and more efficient to run all products on the same infrastructure. Maybe it was also cheaper and better for their ops teams. Maybe they _are_ running on different infrastructure, but with the same providers whose services failed.

Users are frustrated that they can't access any of their favourite social apps. Privacy-concerned users might be suspicious of non-consensual data sharing between the products, since they're connected by both ownership and tech. Where is the line that separates them?

Another example is Facebook corp. The infrastructure is clearly shared in some way between Facebook, Instagram and Whatsapp, meaning we've seen several incidents when all three products went down simultaneously.

From the company's view, it's just that the team building the new feature was dedicated to working on that from its conception, so they had no other backlog of issues to deal with, whereas other feature teams do have backlogs and haven't gotten round to fixing those bugs yet.

If you use feature teams, users might be irritated that you seem to be more concerned with releasing new features than making existing ones work properly, since there are lots of bugs. "They're more concerned about making money than quality software." (sadly often true as well)

I've often felt this way, as a user. From the company's view, it's just that the workload, roadmaps, or priorities between teams are different. Maybe the tech stack and capabilities are also different and that's why there's a mismatch between platforms.

For example, how do you split dev teams? If you go for platform teams, users might be frustrated that their friends can enjoy features that aren't available on their device's platform. They might be annoyed that a certain action or feature is only available on the web app.

Do you ever think about how your infra/structural and process decisions might impact users? Since working in tech, I've often ruminated on the connections between the inner workings of software companies and my own experiences as a user. [thread]

It's not good enough to imply that only the people with tech knowledge will be given the privilege of being able to protect themselves against tracking. We shouldn't be tracking them without consent in the first place. As technologists, we need to do better.

It's true - other companies use tracking pixels and some email clients allow you to disable images, but that doesn't make it okay. It just diverts responsibility. What percentage of people who don't work in tech do you think even know about tracking pixels to disable them?

"We did not consider potential bad actors."
I appreciate @Superhuman's response and actions following criticism, but this sentiment is too common. #Ethics and misuse need to be considered from the outset. Also, "we're not the only ones doing it" is not an acceptable excuse.

Responses to this tweet showing people's complete disregard for #privacy & #ethics is alarming. Allowing users to track _any_ person's location simply by emailing them is dangerous & unacceptable. It's technologists' responsibility to protect from this.

@hogfish Just piling on the proof of the culture to take any responsibility away from people who act inappropriately. All these reasons why I should "just" do this or that as if I'm the one who needs to change because of someone else's actions. It's disgusting.

@hogfish What really irritates me is how they say it as if that means there's no real person behind it, as if computers do this on their own when they're bored, and that makes everything okay. You can do whatever you want to me, as long as you're also trying to scam me or use a bot 🙄🖕

@tottinge @NativeWired @SergeyIRL @katrinbretscher That's what it's like to receive these messages. It's a reminder of a real threat that I have experienced first hand. It's a reminder that I'm not respected or seen as a real person. It's a reminder that I'm not safe. That's why, regardless of anything else, this is not okay.

@tottinge @NativeWired @SergeyIRL @katrinbretscher It doesn't help when others point out that they've been held at gunpoint too or that the mugger only wanted your money. A real threat exists, and every time someone holds you at gunpoint, you're reminded that you are not safe.

@tottinge @NativeWired @SergeyIRL @katrinbretscher It also doesn't matter if they hold up the entire bank you're in. They might not have a real intention to shoot you, but you know from experience that other people will absolutely shoot you and every time someone threatens that, it affects you.

@tottinge @NativeWired @SergeyIRL @katrinbretscher They don't actually intend to shoot you but you don't know for sure that they won't. All you think about is the possibility that they might, and the last time you or someone you know were shot and got really hurt. It doesn't matter how many people this person has mugged.

@tottinge @NativeWired @SergeyIRL @katrinbretscher Some people have died, some have gotten away grazed, others have lived in fear ever since. Living this kind of life where being shot is a serious possibility, a mugger holds you at gunpoint and threatens to shoot you unless you hand over your wallet.

@tottinge @NativeWired @SergeyIRL @katrinbretscher Thanks for acknowledging a blind spot. I'll extend on this analogy to try and explain what it's like: https://t.co/GHzd1WQzhb
Say you live in a bad area where people are shot at all the time. People you know and maybe even you have been shot before.

@ezagroba People try all kinds and can get quite specific in messages. I've even had someone say they saw me on a specific street near my office. Yet, strangers brush it off as nothing because we're not the only ones subjected to these messages and they probably have another motive 🤔🙄

No. Of course not. So don't bring up the scammer / bot response to someone acting inappropriately towards another human being as if that resolves the real person behind any potential scam / bot of any responsibility. This is about _their_ action, not my reaction. 3/3

When you find out that the shooter shot at you with the goal of stealing your money, and used an automatic weapon, is that suddenly okay? Are you instantly fine with what just happened because this person had a purpose beyond simply shooting you and used machinery to do it? 2/3

While I'm irritated at the resurgence of the scammer / bot response, consider this: You're minding your own business when someone suddenly barges in and starts shooting at you. You're affected by being shot, obviously. It kind of puts you in a down mood. 1/3 https://t.co/qU7YJEQzPq

@katrinbretscher @SergeyIRL @NativeWired Or we could hold the actors accountable instead of telling people subjected to these behaviours how to react. I respect that you have your own ways of dealing with these incidents, but please don't tell me how I should deal with them. Comments like that contribute to lost energy.

@katrinbretscher @SergeyIRL @NativeWired Some of them might be scammers but not all are. When I worked in recruitment, I had real candidates who attended interviews ask me to dinner or to visit them. To dismiss these as just scammers is diminishing the negative experiences of people who are subjected to this behaviour.

@TestSheepNZ This is definitely not a lately thing. I've always gotten messages like this. Even when I was working in recruitment, candidates would ask me out to dinner or ask me to go and visit them. It's disgusting.

Bonus / afterthoughts:
- Is someone recognised as the same person when they're
-- happy v sad v angry
-- speaking in a tonal v non-tonal language
-- speaking with a different accent
-- doing an impression of someone else?
5/4

- What #privacy / #dataprotection  rights do the people whose voices were used for #testing have?
- If I work as a tester on a #voicerecognition project or even just something that uses voice commands, can I have all my voice data deleted to prevent misuse and #IDtheft?
4/4 🤔

- Will someone whose voice was recorded at age 9, 17, 43, 78 be recognised as the same person?
- What about people who develop voice altering illnesses?
- What about trans people who alter their voices?
- How can we reliably test these scenarios without waiting? 3/4

- How does #voicerecognition deal with gradual changes in people's voices over time?
- Is there long-term research showing how voice patterns change?
- Do co's who use it as #ID update users' voice patterns / add to the recognition data each time they speak to the user? 2/4

@nicolasedgwick @DanAshby04 @melthetester And although there are certainly people who rally round them, me included, they didn't create the community per se. But they did nurture it and help it to grow. That's where a lot of other orgs fall short and it frustrates me when they claim to give back but I've never seen it.

@nicolasedgwick @DanAshby04 @melthetester Definitely. It has to be more about the individual members than boosting a brand / company / org / corporate agenda. That's why MoT is so great to me. They're a for profit company, but everything they do is for the benefit of the testing community, nothing else.

@nicolasedgwick @DanAshby04 @melthetester I'd say it's the interaction. How can the members be a community if they don't interact with each other? And I mean on a personal level. Leaving trolling or unhelpful comments with no intention of meaningful discussion, for example, doesn't count.
@dsynadinos @DanAshby04 @melthetester Or criterion, whatever 🙄

@dsynadinos @DanAshby04 @melthetester Community goes beyond your beliefs, in my opinion. For example, all Christians aren't in one community. That isn't community, that's religion. Shared beliefs can't be the only criteria. If even argue that it doesn't have to be a criteria at all, in the wider sense.

@DanAshby04 @melthetester But the same argument could be made for those who only attend conferences or even workshops and training but don't talk to anyone else or participate in any other way than being there. There needs to be active engagement, I think.

@DanAshby04 @melthetester That's kind of my point with restricting community just to people who physically get together in the same place. I think there are other ways to engage and participate. I agree that consumption alone isn't enough to be considered part of a community.

@DanAshby04 @melthetester What about those who are never physically at events but participate online, for example? Are they not part of the testing community? If not, would you identify them in another way?
@DanAshby04 @nicolasedgwick @melthetester Just realised that I read and wrote "AiT" but I was thinking AI 🙄 apologies. I agree with you on the mission part, from what I've seen of it so far.

@DanAshby04 @melthetester I think "run by people in the community" is more accurate. For example, I haven't run any events and I don't want to. I might attend them, but even if I don't, it doesn't feel right to say I'm not part of that community just because I don't get involved in physical events.

@DanAshby04 @melthetester No, I think industries and communities are very different things. That's why, IMO, people who have been testing for x long talk about "finding the community" at y stage. To me, it's obvious when you find it. So it's interesting to read other people's perspectives of what it is.
@nicolasedgwick Interesting perspective. Is was actually tempted to post "who / what" because it seemed more fitting to me too, but the original question was "who".

@nicolasedgwick @DanAshby04 @melthetester Apart from maybe AiT, I don't see these as communities as such, or in the same way. More like organisations / brands with a following. The same way that different people could love Starbucks and go all the time, but that doesn't make them a community. Do you know what I mean?

@maaretp @melthetester It seems like you're describing somewhat of a defense strategy. The way I came into the community was more out of a search for knowledge and improvement, so I guess that's the perspective I still carry with me, though I've since found many more great things.
@DanAshby04 @melthetester I don't think a community is for anyone to run. Events are run, clubs are run. Communities are not.

@DanAshby04 @melthetester Yes and yes. But again, I don't think it's just about which events you attend. Some people have never attended these events, but that doesn't mean they're not part of the community, IMO.

@DanAshby04 @melthetester I see us as friends (some closer than others) who all happen to be interested in testing and quality. The original question came up because I was talking about how this community comes together to support people, even if we don't know them personally.

@DanAshby04 @melthetester I also think that one of the things that makes the testing community special (in the way I think Mel is describing) is that we support each other as people; with learning, mental health, discrimination issues, etc.

@DanAshby04 @melthetester I prefer not to look at it so granularly. Again,a community to me is different from, for example, a shared interest group or club. I don't like the idea of saying, "this person isn't part of my community because of where they are or how they work".

@DanAshby04 @melthetester Who mentioned sponsorship stands? 😳 I meant that different people with different beliefs / methodologies go to all kinds of different events, and I don't see that any of the organisers specifically restrict certain people from attending.

@DanAshby04 @melthetester I was just wondering about it because my list of testers are people who I consider to be part of the testing community. Maybe others do the same thing. I used to, but not so much any more, though I want to. I don't think it's just about which events you attend though.
@DanAshby04 @melthetester Like I said to Amanda, I think it would be a real shame to separate or segregate people based on these things. To me, "community" means more than that.

@DanAshby04 @melthetester I don't think they explicitly invite one or the other. Also, ISTQB IME tends to be more well known amongst testers who are newer to the wider community. They pop up at all kinds of events, and people who lean towards another preference also go to lots of different things.

@MsAmandaDean Definitely agree on the diversity. It would be a shame to split people up into separate groups based purely on our differences. That's where a lot of our strengths and interesting discussions come from, IMO.

@maaretp @melthetester "tester community comes from need of teaming up from a perceived position of lower power."
Can you elaborate on that?
@MsAmandaDean Dan said something similar. I'll ask you the same question: do you really think they're separate, or just subsets of the wider community?

@DanAshby04 @melthetester For example, I've been added to a lot of dev lists on twitter. Is that because the owners of those lists consider me to be part of the / a dev community in the same way that we consider some devs, agile coaches, etc. to be part of our testing one(s)? 2/2

@DanAshby04 @melthetester Do you think they are really separate, or just subsets of the wider community? I agree about being part of other communities. Though I wonder if we are already considered to be without realising it. 1/2
@melthetester This was a dev asking me too and they were also very surprised.
Someone just asked me, "who is the testing community?" How would you describe / explain it? Do you think other communities in tech exist in the same way?

@TestingRants @hogfish Mate, can you not? 😅 Someone just told me, "I can't understand your Chinese accent". As a woman with a very broad Scottish accent, it pissed me off. The accent has been mistaken for American, which I understand, but be less obvious with your racial assumptions 😠

@TestingRants That is a problem. I haven't seen a term that I think specifically includes mixed race people. Again, part of the difficultly is how an individual person identifies. I imagine the whole white privilege thing can be tricky for part-white people too.

@lisacrispin @MaikNog Yeah, I've never heard of it being used as a positive thing. URM could work. It might be too general in some contexts though, depending on whether someone is specifically referring to race / ethnicity as opposed to gender, able bodied-ness, etc.

@MaikNog I understand your point re "and the rest". There's no practical solution to this, unfortunately. However, I don't think POC or "colour" have the same meaning to you as they do to me. I'd be highly offended if someone tried to tell me what colour I am.

@MaikNog In the UK, "Asian" mostly only includes the groups you mentioned, whereas I was constantly told that "Asian" doesn't include me because I'm somehow the "wrong kind". Everyone's experiences of these things will be different in some way.

@MaikNog So you also don't think they'd consider themselves part of a minority ethnic? Neither of us are in the groups you mentioned, so we are both speculating and can't speak for anyone else. Like all identity matters, this is highly personal.
@MaikNog What do you mean Asian subcontinent? Why is that not included under "Asian"?

@MaikNog Thanks for sharing. In what way? Minority ethnicities doesn't point to any specific ones, as far as I can tell. It's an addition to the BA, not an explanation, I think. Plus, POC does nothing to include those groups either.

It seems to sometimes be associated with the UK, maybe because it originated there, I don't know. But the acronym doesn't specify anything to do with being British. If you have other suggestions for more inclusive terms, feel free to share. This also applies to terms for gender.

Since I just shared this with someone else, I thought I'd post it here too.  If you're looking for an alternative term to #POC, you might consider #BAME.  BAME stands for Black, Asian, Minority Ethnic. It's not perfect either, but I think it moves closer towards inclusivity. https://t.co/lXyd9GmVlb

I’d appreciate your thoughts on (not) publishing the blog, and suggestions of conferences that might appreciate the talk. The abstract is pictured below. If you’d like to help me raise awareness of this perspective and the availability of this talk, please RT. Thanks for reading. https://t.co/sjIXyYVX7q

I was going to write a blog post offering "Pipeline: A Chinese Woman's Journey in(to) a White Man's World" to other conferences, and ask for suggestions of where else to submit it to, but it seems to make sense to do that in this thread.

I don't see anyone else like me talking about the things I want to talk about. #Representation is so important, and I didn't even realise how much lack of representation impacted me growing up when I wrote this blog: https://t.co/mzWlvMT0tx

I’ve reviewed hundreds of abstracts for conferences and remind myself of other valid reasons why this talk might have been rejected. I don’t know if I should publish the blog, but I know that I want to give this talk. I want to be heard, somehow.

The talk was rejected and I’m currently awaiting feedback. This is not the first talk I’ve had rejected, but it stings. It hurts because from the moment I started creating it, I feared that no one would want to hear about how no one wants to hear about it.

It aims to offer insight to those privileged enough not to have experienced some of the things I have. It also highlights how the #racism and #sexism already embedded in #technology can affect real people and negatively shape their world views.

I recently submitted a talk called, “#Pipeline: A Chinese Woman’s Journey in(to) a White Man’s World”. It’s a series of short stories about my experiences as a Chinese woman in #tech. It gives real examples to help people make up their own minds about what problems exist in #IT.

When I re-read the blog and think about rewriting it in a more composed way, I can’t. I’m too angry again, and I’m not an angry person. I’ve self-censored for what I believe are the right reasons, but it feels very ironic and adds to the frustration.

I didn’t publish it, but I think about it a lot. When I experience #racism, microaggressions; when I see talk of including #POC and feel completely left out. I want to share my perspective, but I don’t want to be misinterpreted and attacked.

I didn’t publish it because I was genuinely worried that it would be misinterpreted as an attack on black people, or anyone who does identify as #POC. It was not and is not. But I was very angry and frustrated, and it reads that way.

I’m #Chinese and I do not identify as #POC.
 I do not appreciate implications that I should identify as POC or be excluded from #diversity discussions.

Last year, I wrote a blog about this, and some of the #racism and #exclusion I’ve experienced as a Chinese person.

In total, it took us less than five minutes to make decisions that made our video more inclusive, and it wasn't difficult at all. I hope you'll join us in making your own small steps towards diversity and being more inclusive.

[End]

I'm pleased to say that these diverse characters were already available in @MaibornWolff's library of illustrations, so we didn't have to ask for these characters to be made for our video, we just needed more images of them doing different things in the story.

I like that Charlie can be a name for a man or a woman. In future, I'd like to think of and include some names that are less commonly associated with Western culture too, to keep moving towards better diversity and inclusion.

The tester was the only character with a name - Charlie. He was named after a dog we often see on the way to a client (real name: probably not Charlie). This is Charlie the dog. https://t.co/i2JED4FaR4

In all honesty, there were more readily available images of the one we chose for the tester, and I didn't see this one until we had custom images made for these roles to fit the story in the video. I'm also not sure about a "one size fits all" lead for representation.

This further helped to get away from the idea of a "token" non-white person and also balanced the genders by having another character that most would interpret as a woman. Why didn't we use this image as the main character, so there could be a woman lead?

While going through the storyboard, we realised there was another character needed to imply that the team is larger than just three people. This small supporting role was represented by the character below. https://t.co/GTYOvzo3NF
I didn't like the stereotypical image of the woman in the business role and the man in the technical role, so we swapped these characters around to challenge this stereotype.

The main supporting character is the PO, and my first thought was to make this a woman. Out of the characters and images we had available, that would leave another male character for the developer. This didn't sit well with me.
It's important to me to that not all characters in the video are white men. I didn't want the only non-white person to be a "token" non-white person, so we made him the main character - the tester.

[Thread on small, practical steps towards #diversity and #inclusion in #tech]

Before asking, "didn't anyone test this?" ask:
1. Would I have tested for this?
2. Are the bugs I find always immediately fixed?

Have a little empathy for your fellow tester and use it as an opportunity to think of scenarios you might be missing.

I'm exhausted but it's been incredible. Thank you to everyone who has been a part of this special, jam packed 6 weeks. I now need to remember not to make myself so busy again in future! It's okay to say "no" and "not now".

I've also:
- Met >150 testers 
- Made new connections 
- Turned online friends into real life ones 
- Strengthened existing friendships 
- Published 2 important articles about sexual harassment and diversity 
- Learned been inspired 
- Taught and inspired others

In the last 6 weeks I've:
- Been to 4 conferences (#TestBash x3, #AgileTD) 
- Spoken publicly 5 times (2 scheduled, 3x 99 sec talks)
- Facilitated 4 interactive sessions 
- Been in 8 cities in 3 countries across 2 continents 
- Traveled >60 hours
